newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: OUB sees Singapore growing 6-7 pct 1997.
newsitem.headline: OUB sees Singapore growing 6-7 pct 1997.

text.p: Overseas Union Bank Ltd's president and chief executive officer Peter Seah said on Friday he expected Singapore's economy to grow by six to seven percent in 1997.
"I see a 6-7 percent GDP growth," Seah told Reuters in an interview.
He said this was still "a very healthy growth percentage so there should be a lot of opportunities for business."
Singapore experienced rapid economic growth through the early 1990s with a jump of 8.8 percent in its gross domestic product (GDP) in 1995.
But the recent slump in the global electronics industry, particularly in the United States, has slowed growth this year.
Electronics and related products account for almost half Singapore's total industrial production and around 60 percent of its non-oil exports.

The government predicts Singapore's growth will average between seven and eight percent for 1996 as a whole. A recent Reuters poll of 11 leading economists forecast growth of 7.2 percent in Singapore's GDP in 1997.
OUB is one of Singapore's big four domestic banks.
